title: Watercolor Fundamentals Part 1
location: Rileystreet Art Supply,103 Maxwell Ct, Santa Rosa, CA 95401, USA
description:
Instructor: Anne Millett

This is a 6-class series, meeting 6 Tuesdays
10:30AM-1:00PM
Location: Santa Rosa Store
$270.00


*Additional: Separate $20.00 plus tax Materials Fee paid to Anne at the first class, for the high-quality Arches #140 cold press watercolor paper. Brushes, palettes, high-quality watercolor paint, and set-ups for use during class will be provided.*

There will be a materials fee of $15 plus tax for the series.


Watercolor Fundamentals - Part 1

This class focuses on the simple delight of mixing color with water, brushing it on paper, and watching what happens as it moves and dries. You will learn easy ways to create paintings that are all about color and the sometimes unpredictable nature of water.

No drawing skills are needed.

In this class we will explore the basic principles of watercolor painting. Learn or refresh your understanding of brush handling, brush care and setting up, the benefits of ‚Äúgood paper‚Äù, watercolor lights and darks, flat and graded washes, wet-on-wet techniques such as charging, wet-on-dry techniques such as glazing, color wheel, color theory, color mixing, and more. Simple applications of these techniques invite you to experiment and play.

This class is designed for adults 18+

$270 for 6 classes, 2.5 hours each class
Payable via check, cash, or Zelle.

*Brushes, palettes, set-ups, and paint will be provided.*


To see Anne's work and to learn more about this class, please visit her website at: http://www.miraaster.com https://www.miraaster.com/ www.miraaster.com

Watercolor Fundamentals Part 3

You‚Äôve experienced Part 1, you‚Äôve experienced Part 2, and now let‚Äôs dive into more water in Part 3! More water leads to more spontaneity and deepens our focus in the moment. Loose florals, imagined landscapes, and abstractions are painted wet-into-wet style in multiple layers. Refining our abilities to work with the water keeps us open to possibilities and surprises in our paintings as they emerge.

This class is designed for adults 18+

Start your morning with traditional yogic breathwork beginning with purification techniques. title: Renewed in Nature at Jack London State Historic Park
description: Join a restorative wellness gathering set within the natural beauty of Jack London State Historic Park. Surrounded by towering redwoods and peaceful landscapes, this experience invites you to slow down, reconnect with nature, and find a sense of connection.¬† As part of the park‚Äôs seasonal programming, this event celebrates the quiet magic of winter and the sense of renewal that comes with the start of a new year. Explore gentle forest trails, allowing the sights, sounds, and stillness of the forest to calm the mind and refresh the spirit. Enjoy a guided walk with moments of reflection, forest bathing, and gentle yoga, all designed to help you feel grounded and refreshed. Step into the forest, embrace the season, and leave feeling renewed. This hike will be about 3.5 miles roundtrip on uneven terrain. Sturdy walking shoes and weather appropriate layers are recommended.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: The Art Of Acrylics
description: Suzanne will demonstrate each week as students follow along with weekly painting projects, exploring techniques such as layering thick and thin paint, using gels and palette knife, and applying color theories. Students can work on their own projects as well. Whether you're a beginner or looking to refine your skills, this class covers everything you need to know. You'll get informed instruction on how to begin a piece, from choosing the right materials to selecting the perfect color palette. We'll dive into composition techniques to help you craft a balanced, captivating piece, and walk you through the finishing touches that bring your work to life. Suzanne's artwork ranges from portraits, figurative genre, landscapes and caricatures. She has exhibited in juried shows including The Society of Illustrators in New York and for 10 years at the Southern California Laguna Beach Art Festival. She has taught classes and workshops for many years and led lecture-demos at art associations from California to Washington State. For enrollment and supply list, please text or call Suzanne Carson at 707 888 2083

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9‚ÄìMarch 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of¬†bonsai and the season‚Äôs first flowers.¬†Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year‚Äôs all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai‚Äîtrees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot¬†bonsai¬†take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal‚Äîreminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from¬†hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through¬†Hanami Strolls‚Äîguided walks through the Garden‚Äôs Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

Unlock your creativity with our Beginning Watercolor Class, designed for beginners and advanced beginners alike! Dive into the vibrant world of watercolor and master the techniques to create stunning artwork.

  * Instructor: Eva Mautner

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit:  Color of Love
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE¬† 1/15/26

**FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE**

EXHIBIT DATES:¬† January 26 ‚Äì February 22, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 ‚Äì 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery‚Äôs free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.¬† Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artists, **Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich** present the **Color of Love,** paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.¬† Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.¬† In Gray‚Äôs ‚ÄúLove Abstractly‚Äù an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color. ¬†Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her ‚ÄúBowl of Strawberries,‚Äù ¬†fruit rendered so realistically, one‚Äôs mouth waters. ¬†Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays ‚Äì tulips and scarlet buglers.¬† Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta‚Äôs jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in ‚ÄúRaven Heart‚Äù and Rapp‚Äôs little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in ‚ÄúFoxy Flowers.‚Äù¬† Shore‚Äôs ‚ÄúShowering You with Gifts‚Äù catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.¬† ‚ÄúAs we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine‚Äôs Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,‚Äù noted Gray.¬† ¬†

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Laura Roney‚Äôs Dance!,** a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.¬† And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.¬† In ‚ÄúHold Me Tight‚Äù one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine‚Äôs Day.¬† Another couple joyfully whoops it up in ‚ÄúBust a Move.‚Äù Bring on the music ‚Äì these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am ‚Äì 6 pm.¬†¬†¬† **www.upstairsart gallery.net**

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

description:
Schedule

Location

Intermediate

Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$225 ‚Äì Registration CostAdvance your drawing skills with deep study of composition, value, and technique. Strengthen your creative process through focused practice.

About the Class

In this class, we will explore composition, value, and other aspects of drawing but on a deeper level. Beginning drawing classes have a lot of ground to cover so the concepts are skimmed over in order to give you exposure to as many as possible. Next-level drawing takes the time to do a deeper dive into some of the principles of drawing. When drawing we use limited tools which allow us to isolate both our strengths and weaknesses. Using this opportunity to really investigate our own process will serve to strengthen all aspects of our creative work. Drawing can be a challenge but when you see how it enhances the creative process, you will know it is worth it. This class is suitable for students who have a basic understanding of drawing and want to work on their skills. Please bring the following materials to class: 20‚Ä≥ x 26‚Ä≥ drawing board with clips, 18 ‚Äúx 24‚Äù Strathmore drawing pad \(other brands are fine as long as the paper is drawing quality\), soft willow charcoal, compressed charcoal \(Char-kole brand black\), white plastic eraser, notebook, Staedtler drawing pencils 2B and 6B, Pigma micron pens black \(one fine-tip and one medium-tip\).Membership has its benefits

title: God of our Heart, God of our Realization
description:
Rosicrucians AMORC, Santa Rosa, CA
A focal point of the Rosicrucian teachings is mysticism, the conscious union of the self with the Divine or God. The centrality of mysticism to our Order is reflected in the very name of our Order, Ancient Mystical Order Rosae Crucis. An evolving personal conception and realization of the Divine is part of the spiritual journey of Rosicrucian students, reflected in the Rosicrucian invocation, ‚ÄúGod of our Heart, God or our Realization.‚Äù During this teleconference, Julian Johnson will lead us in exploring the dominant conceptions of the Divine which are presented in the earliest monographs of the Rosicrucian studies, in addition to the Rosicrucian conception of the Divine or Absolute. We will also look at how modern neuroscience surprisingly reveals connections between our conceptions of God and our body and mind.

**Please RSVP to access log-in link. Click Attend Online button below.**

title: Creative Flow: Explore, Create, Renew
description:
Schedule

Wednesdays, February 4 ‚Äì February 25, 2026 5:30 PM ‚Äì 8:30 PM

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Categories: Drawing & Painting, Wellness

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$200 ‚Äì Registration Cost $25 ‚Äì Materials Fee $225 ‚Äì Total Registration CostExplore body, mind, and imagination through movement, art, and writing in this beginner-friendly, four-week class. No experience needed-just curiosity!

What you‚Äôll do

Based on the Tamalpa Life/Art Process, founded by Anna Halprin, this four-week class invites participants to explore the connection between body, mind, and imagination through gentle movement, art-making, and writing. Each session blends simple, creative activities designed to transform life experiences into art and open new possibilities for personal renewal. In a supportive and beginner-friendly environment, students will deepen self-awareness, express emotions, and discover fresh perspectives. No prior dance or art experience is required‚Äîjust curiosity and an open heart. Course Format and Weekly Outline: Session 1 ‚Äì The Call & Crossing the Threshold: Mapping the Self Theme: Where am I now? Practices: Guided movement warm-up; sensory awareness; movement exploration of stepping toward/away from a ‚Äúthreshold‚Äù; body mapping with paint/collage; reflective writing. Outcome: Participants identify their current state and set creative intentions for the series. Session 2 ‚Äì Trials & Allies: Shadows and Strengths Theme: Meeting obstacles and discovering resources. Practices: Movement exploration of ‚Äúallies and shadows‚Äù; expressive drawing/painting; optional mask or small clay object; reflective writing; small-group witnessing. Outcome: Students recognize inner strengths and gain flexible tools for navigating emotions and challenges. Session 3 ‚Äì Ordeal & Transformation: Release and the Boon Theme: Releasing old patterns and discovering new insights. Practices: Grounding movement; movement ritual exploring ‚Äúwhat I am ready to release‚Äù; creation of the ‚ÄúBoon‚Äù object or image; reflective writing. Outcome: Participants experience personal renewal and create a symbolic object representing newly gained insight. Session 4 ‚Äì Return with the Elixir: Integration & Wholeness Theme: Carrying creative insight back into everyday life. Practices: Movement exploration of ‚Äúpathways of return‚Äù; creation of a triptych \(Before / Crossing / Return\); gallery walk and group witnessing; closing ritual with shared intentions. Outcome: Students integrate learning and leave with practical creative practices for ongoing self- discovery and stress relief. Learning Outcomes: 1. Develop greater self-awareness by exploring personal experiences through movement, art-making, and reflective writing. 2. Use creative tools for well-being, including techniques for emotional expression, personal renewal, and stress reduction. 3. Strengthen confidence and connection through supportive group activities and experiments with expressive movement and visual art.

description:

Our Cool Team program brings neighbors or friends together so that we can take care of each other while we take care of the planet.

title: Cheese & Butter Classes
description:
Join award-winning cheesemaker Sheana Davis and wine expert Ben Sessions for unforgettable¬†cheese and butter making classes. Perfect for team building, celebrations, and educational events, our classes are interactive, fun, and easy for everyone. 

From classes on how to make Creme de Ricotta wheel to Mozzarella Pulling to butter-making classes, guests will always leave with a creamy treat to take home \(if it makes it that far!\) ‚Äì so bring a small cooler with you.¬† 

Food has a remarkable ability to bring people together. 

Cheesemaking classes are perfect for team-building activities, company meetings, team celebrations, staff events, corporate fun, bridal parties, couples classes, girlfriend getaway weekends, LGBT events, EBT education courses, and more. Classes held year-round on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, 12:00-2:00 and 3:30-5:30pm. 

See the full schedule of all our cheese and butter making classes here.¬† 

With each class, we give back to the community by providing meals for food-insecure seniors in Sonoma Valley. After learning how to make cheese, our guests can prepare these meals and write personal notes for the seniors on the lids.¬† 

Join us in making a positive impact while having fun and learning a new skill.¬†¬† 

Your Cheesemaking Experience: 



Begin with local wine and an artisanal cheese tasting.

Learn to make cheese and compound butter with everyday ingredients and tools.

Enjoy specialized classes for dishes like lasagna and gourmet grilled cheeses.

Exclusive guest cheesemakers often share their techniques.

Ideal for corporate events, bridal parties, getaways, and more.



Sheana and Ben pride themselves on using ingredients readily available in any local grocery store, with cooking supplies used reside in most home cooks‚Äô kitchens. Guest cheesemakers are often available to showcase their own cheeses and techniques, making the class a truly unique experience. 

Check the schedule for¬†Wine Country-based cheesemaking classes.¬† 

Customize Your Class:To arrange private or corporate classes at venues like Sonoma Fairmont Mission Inn or Silverado Resort, contact us at¬†sheanadavis@gmail.com. We can help create a unique and unforgettable experience for your entire group! Private and corporate classes may be arranged and are hosted at various Wine Country venues, including The Fairmont Sonoma Mission Inn, Silverado Resort, The Lodge in Sonoma, and private homes and estates. 

To register: 

https://theepicureanconnection.com/events/

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: Yoga Vinyasa Krama
description:
Nataraja School of Traditional Yoga
**Yoga Vinyasa Krama - Thursdays 9-10:30am**
**Soft Medicine Sanctuary - Loft**

Experience physical health & fitness, pranic flow, vital energy & stillness - through intelligent architecture with the metaphysics of deep conscious breathing & slow motion, yogic breathwork, mantra/sound/vibration, mudra, subtle & contemplative practices.

Yoga Vinyasa Krama is a comprehensive hatha-raja yogic system for purification, developing concentration, neuromuscular fitness and conditioning, mastering the breath, awakening subtle energy and stilling the mind. Based on deep breathing & the subtle movement of prana directed into the cartilage tissue, sinuous musculature, internal organs, nerve pathways and nadis. It has over 700 intelligently sequenced slow, conscious breath powered with precision movement variations with pause (vinyasas), exploring many aesthetic variations of each posture to correctly establish the main asanas while the mind merges with the breath.
Includes drishti, pratikriyas, bandha, vaseth, mudra, mantra, surya & ding namaskar with breath & mantra, cleansing kriyas, Himalayan pranayama including including ujjayi variations, heating & cooling breaths, solar, lunar & soli-lunar nadi shuddhi practices, pranava & samantraka pranayama, pratyahara, subtle & contemplative practices in 12 kramas (sequences).

The whole process gradually transforms the body and mind, releasing old patterns of physical and mental tension and dysfunctional patterns of movement, providing tonic, energetic and psychophysiological effects. This system is presented from the teachings Srivatsa Ramaswami learned through his over 33 years of one on one study with Sri Krishnamacharya and teachings from a similar Himalayan method.

This ongoing class will explore the entire system of 12 Kramas with each class focusing on a particular krama (sequence) & pranayama & contemplative practices.

Please practice on an empty stomach. Morning beverage ok but please take it 30min or more before class.

$25 Drop In, Discounted Class Passes & Memberships
Register -[https://momence.com/Soft-Medicine-Sanctuary/Yoga-Vinyasa-Krama-/122789095?skipPreview=true](https://momence.com/Soft-Medicine-Sanctuary/Yoga-Vinyasa-Krama-/122789095?skipPreview=true)

title: Oil Portrait in Four Steps with Maggie Parr
location: Rileystreet Art Supply,103 Maxwell Ct, Santa Rosa, CA 95401, USA
description:
Instructor: Maggie Parr
Thursday mornings from February 19th-March12th
10:00 am-1:00 pm
$225 + materials
Limited to 10 students (first 4 students to register get a free ¬Ω hour private consult with
Maggie)

Oil painting doesn‚Äôt have to be intimidating! In just four weeks, students will paint a portrait in the indirect style, starting with a grey value study, building up with layers, and finishing with powerful details. The final result always surprises people: just by following basic rules, anyone can create a beautiful oil portrait that glows. Even abstract
painters can benefit from learning these techniques. Knowing how oil painting works give us more confidence to develop our own authentic creative voice. As Maggie says, ‚ÄúYou gotta learn the rules to break the rules.‚Äù


Maggie Parr started her career destroying Lichtenstein prints that didn‚Äôt make the edition at Gemini G.E.L., where she learned that the behemoth art market would not be conducive to her spiritual and personal paintings. She started working as a show designer at Walt Disney Imagineering, where for the next three decades, she designed theme park attractions around the world. She also expanded into book illustration, murals, portraits,
comics, and eventually, writing books and scripts for television. Along the way, she studied with master teachers like Steve Huston, Jeremy Lipking, and
Joseph Q. Daily. She spent years experimenting to find her own creative voice‚Äîa fusion of expressionism and realism. She got an MFA and taught at the college level, then developed her own teaching methods for private and group study.

Today, Maggie maintains a thriving business creating custom art and designs for corporations, individuals, and non-profits. She teaches other artists to utilize classical rendering techniques so they can confidently break the rules in the service of their own
work. And she coaches creatives in search of deeper authenticity, healing, and self- actualization.

Please follow the link to register for this class https://www.parrcreate.com/page/676799 www.parrcreate.com/page/691159 https://www.parrcreate.com/page/691159 https://www.parrcreate.com/page/691159

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9‚ÄìMarch 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of¬†bonsai and the season‚Äôs first flowers.¬†Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year‚Äôs all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai‚Äîtrees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot¬†bonsai¬†take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal‚Äîreminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from¬†hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through¬†Hanami Strolls‚Äîguided walks through the Garden‚Äôs Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative

Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

title: Cuentos con Ritmo (Stories with Rhythm)
description:
Cuentos con Ritmo \(Stories with Rhythm\)

Cuentos con Ritmo | Cuentos \* M√∫sica \* Movimiento 

Presentado por Colors of Spanish 

Cuentos con Ritmo es una oportunidad √∫nica semanal para ni√±os de 1 a 5 a√±os y sus familias, el cual aporta alegr√≠a, comprensi√≥n y aprecio por la lengua espa√±ola a toda la comunidad. Durante Cuentos con Ritmo, los peque√±os visitantes y sus familias participan de forma l√∫dica en historias interactivas con m√∫sica y movimiento fortaleciendo nuestra diversa comunidad y entusiasmo por la lengua meta. 

Cuentos con Ritmo es presentado por Guadalupe Tausch en colaboraci√≥n con la organizaci√≥n que fund√≥, Colors of Spanish. Originaria del estado de Guanajuato en M√©xico, tiene una maestr√≠a en espa√±ol con √©nfasis en la adquisici√≥n de una segunda lengua para la primera infancia y contin√∫a sus estudios enfocada en la primera infancia especializ√°ndose en la adquisici√≥n de idiomas a trav√©s de la m√∫sica/movimiento. Colors of Spanish ofrece talleres para profesores, bibliotecarios y cuidadores y organiza programas de cuentos en espa√±ol con m√∫sica y movimiento en escuelas, bibliotecas y museos locales. www.colorsofspanish.org 

Cuentos con Ritmo | Cuentos \* M√∫sica \* Movimiento 

Presented by Colors of Spanish 

Cuentos con Ritmo \(Stories with Rhythm\) is a weekly one-of-a-kind opportunity for children ages 1-5 and their families that brings joy, understanding and appreciation for the Spanish language to Spanish- and English-speaking speakers alike. During Cuentos con Ritmo, young visitors and their families playfully engage in interactive stories with music and movement that build community and an excitement for language! 

Cuentos con Ritmo is presented by Guadalupe Tausch in collaboration with the organization she founded, Colors of Spanish. Originally from the state of Guanajuato in M√©xico, she has a master‚Äôs degree in Spanish with emphasis in second language acquisition for early childhood and continues her study of childhood and music/movement trainings. Colors of Spanish provides workshops for teachers, librarians and caregivers and hosts Spanish story time with music & movement programs at local schools, libraries, and museums. www.colorsofspanish.org 

Designed for kids 1-5, families, and siblings.

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit:  Color of Love
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE¬† 1/15/26

**FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE**

EXHIBIT DATES:¬† January 26 ‚Äì February 22, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 ‚Äì 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery‚Äôs free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.¬† Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artists, **Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich** present the **Color of Love,** paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.¬† Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.¬† In Gray‚Äôs ‚ÄúLove Abstractly‚Äù an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color. ¬†Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her ‚ÄúBowl of Strawberries,‚Äù ¬†fruit rendered so realistically, one‚Äôs mouth waters. ¬†Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays ‚Äì tulips and scarlet buglers.¬† Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta‚Äôs jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in ‚ÄúRaven Heart‚Äù and Rapp‚Äôs little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in ‚ÄúFoxy Flowers.‚Äù¬† Shore‚Äôs ‚ÄúShowering You with Gifts‚Äù catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.¬† ‚ÄúAs we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine‚Äôs Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,‚Äù noted Gray.¬† ¬†

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Laura Roney‚Äôs Dance!,** a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.¬† And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.¬† In ‚ÄúHold Me Tight‚Äù one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine‚Äôs Day.¬† Another couple joyfully whoops it up in ‚ÄúBust a Move.‚Äù Bring on the music ‚Äì these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am ‚Äì 6 pm.¬†¬†¬† **www.upstairsart gallery.net**

title: Grape to Glass Experience
description:
Explore the heart and soul of winemaking with our Grape to Glass Tour & Tasting at Dutton Estate Winery. Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: SIR Branch 17 presents: Building Homes, Community & Hope
description:
Enrich Your Life ‚Äì SIR Branch 17 ‚Äì Building Homes, Community & Hope

SIR Branch 17 will hold its next meeting on Thursday, February 19, 2026.¬† Our speaker will be Rachel Jeffries from Habitat for Humanity of Sonoma County. ¬†Habitat for Humanity brings people together to build homes, communities, and hope.¬† They build strength, stability and self-reliance through shelter.¬† People in your community and all over the world partner with Habitat for Humanity to build or improve a place they can call home.¬† Rachel will tell us what they have done in Sonoma County.

RESERVATIONS REQUIRED.¬† Members pay for lunch but its Free for invited first-time guests.¬† Contact us for more details on how to receive an invitation.

SIR, Inc. is a California non-profit organization that provides social activities for men and their partners whose mission is: ‚ÄúTo enhance the lives of our members through fun activities, luncheons and events while making Friends for Life‚Äù.

SIR Branch 17 meets in Santa Rosa for socializing, lunch, and an interesting speaker every 3rd Thursday of the month.¬† In addition to our luncheon, we organize other activities, including Golf, Bocce, Poker, Bridge, Dining Out \(with & without partners\); Global Affairs; Pickleball; Coffee Club; Beer, Wine & Spirits; Book Club; Hiking/Walking; and more!

Live longer and happier with good friends while enjoying fun activities.¬† We don‚Äôt raise money, have a political agenda, a religious orientation, or sell anything.¬† For more information, visit us at www.SIR17.org or contact us by phone at \(707\) 596-8027 or email at SIRBr17@gmail.com

title: Practice Public Speaking at Downtown Toastmasters
description:
Our meeting theme on January 8th is "Room to Grow." You are welcome to practice your public speaking with a 1-2 minute table topic extemporaneous speeches from a prompt. What better way to start the New Year by taking the first step into confident public speaking?

We start the meetings promptly at 12:05pm, so come early to sign in and mingle. We are a small group and meet twice monthly. It's not overwhelming and there's plenty of chances to participate.

Ready to boost your public speaking skills? Come hang out with fellow enthusiasts and practice in a super friendly, in-person setting. Whether you're a newbie or a pro, Downtown Toastmasters is all about growing your confidence and connecting with awesome people. Don't miss out on a great chance to speak up and shine!

Guests Welcome!

title: Barbies & Bags Workshop
description:
Schedule

Sunday, February 15, 2026 1:00 PM ‚Äì 4:00 PM

Location

Room 201, Fiber Arts Studio

Experience Level

All Levels

Kids, Programming, Sustainability

Age\(s\)

All Ages are welcome to attend Children under 16 must be accompanied by an adult

$25 ‚Äì One Bag or Doll Entry $40 ‚Äì Two Bags or Dolls entryTransform plastic dolls and create upcycled bags from trash into unique art. Join our hands-on Trashion workshop for the Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction.

About the Class

This hands-on workshop invites participants to rescue and reinvent plastic dolls \(Barbies, Kens, and dolls that are under 12 inches\) often destined for landfills, where they can take 20 to 500 years to decompose. As part of Trashion Season, join us for the beloved Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction \(April 3 ‚Äì 25\) where discarded materials are transformed into small-scale works of art for a good cause. Together, we‚Äôll reclaim these forgotten figures and reimagine them as expressive, one-of-a-kind artworks for submission to the gallery exhibit and auction. New this year: Bags! In addition to dolls, we‚Äôre expanding the exhibit to include bags‚Äîthink totes, clutches, cross bagsm fanny packs, coin purses, and backpacks. Just like the Trashion runway, the only rule is that your piece must be made from unconventional materials and/or upcycled/used textiles. Participants will have access to access to sewing machines, hot glue guns, irons, hair dryers and other creative tools as well of a wide selection of trash and upcycled materials to bring their vision to life. BYOT \(Bring your own trash\) is also welcome and encouraged! The workshop registration is your application fee to the gallery exhibit! Come play, experiment, and collaborate while contributing to a dynamic gallery exhibit that raises funds for Sonoma Community Center programming through the auction. It‚Äôs a joy to see your art find a new home‚Äîand to be part of a creative community turning trash into treasure.

Thank you to Recology Sonoma-Marin for donating Barbies & Dolls for our gallery exhibit every year.

title: Latin Cooking Class with Chef Carlos of Guiso Latin Fusion
description:
Latin Cooking Class with Chef Carlos of Guiso Latin Fusion - 2/19

$125.00

Join Sonoma Family Meal and locally-renowned chef Carlos Mojica of Guiso Latin Fusion in Healdsburg for a Latin cooking class at the Sonoma Family Meal Kitchen! The hands-on, collaborative class will last 2.5 hours, with time to enjoy your meal together at the end.

Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned cook or just starting out, this class will offer a fun, engaging learning environment, while raising funds for Sonoma Family Meal‚Äôs free culinary job training and food-security programs.

If you haven‚Äôt been to the SFM Kitchen yet, this class is also the perfect chance to visit and experience where the magic takes place and how the work gets done.

WHEN: Thursday February 19th, 5-7:30pm WHERE: SFM community kitchen, 1370A Redwood Way, Petaluma

THE MENU: TBD

ABOUT THE CHEF:

Chef Carlos was born in El Salvador, where his passion for cooking began in the kitchen with his grandmother and mother, creating simple yet flavorful family meals. After his family migrated to the United States, Carlos worked at his uncle‚Äôs restaurant in Sebastopol, further deepening his love for food. While attending Piner High School, in Santa Rosa, he joined a newly established culinary program, where he learned professional kitchen skills and participated in local food competitions with renowned chefs like Guy Fieri and Rich Nolan. In 2008, his high school team won first place in the Santa Rosa Iron Chef competition. During this time, Carlos also took on the responsibility of cooking family meals, solidifying his dream of becoming a chef.¬†

After graduating, Carlos started at Jackson‚Äôs in Santa Rosa as a dishwasher but quickly worked his way up through various kitchen roles, impressing his colleagues with his dedication and skill. His hard work caught the attention of two restaurateurs, who offered him a sous chef position at their new restaurant. While thriving in this role, Carlos realized his passion for showcasing Latin cuisine and decided to pursue further education. He earned an associate degree from Santa Rosa Junior College‚Äôs culinary program and took additional courses at the Culinary Institute of America \(CIA\) Greystone, St. Helena focusing on pastry and butchery. Next up, Chef Carlos was the head of food development at La Tortilla Factory in Santa Rosa, creating new recipes and products.¬†

At 24, Carlos saved $60,000 from playing in a popular, award winning family band and flipping a house with his father. In 2014, he found a small restaurant space in Healdsburg and, with his father as a partner, opened Guiso Latin Fusion on October 15, 2015. Drawing inspiration from Central and South America, Carlos built the restaurant‚Äôs reputation organically, eventually gaining recognition from a San Francisco Chronicle food writer, which propelled his success.

For Carlos, food is art, and every dish tells a story rooted in his culture and childhood. He strives to create a family-like atmosphere in his restaurant, where guests feel connected and leave with memorable experiences. Beyond running his restaurant, Carlos mentors young chefs, develops a ros√© wine brand called BELI‚ÄôS, and continues to ‚ÄúLive a Flavorful Life.‚Äù His motto, ‚ÄúCook My Culture,‚Äù reflects his deep connection to his roots and his passion for creating meaningful culinary experiences.

AWARDS

\+Best Chef, 2025 Healdsburg, CA Healdsburg Tribune \+The 100 Best Restaurants in America by OpenTable 2025 \+Multiple Diners choice Awards in 2020, 2022, 2023, 2024, 2025 \+Top 100 places to eat in U.S 2024 by Yelp

title: Oil Painting Atelier: Guided Growth & Project Realization
description:
Thursdays, January 8 ‚Äì February 26, 2026 5:00 PM ‚Äì 8:00 PM

Experience Level

Intermediate and Advanced

Event Category: Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$350 ‚Äì Registration Cost

A mentored studio for long-term oil painting projects with personalized guidance, weekly reviews, and support tailored to each artist‚Äôs level and goals.

What you‚Äôll do

This continuous Atelier studio offers sustained, personalized mentorship for students working on long-term oil painting projects. It is structured to serve artists at various stages of development, from those applying foundational knowledge to advanced students exploring profound expressive concepts.

Phase 1: Project Proposal & Private Consultation: All students submit a project proposal. You will meet individually and privately with the instructor to define the scope, set challenging yet achievable goals based on your current skill level, and create a comprehensive roadmap for the duration of the course. This ensures a productive and focused experience, regardless of whether you are a recent beginner or an advanced painter.

Phase 2: Weekly Problem-Solving Studio: You work independently on your project, benefiting from the structure of a studio environment. The instructor conducts weekly, dedicated review time, providing customized guidance. This support scales precisely to your needs, ensuring you receive the appropriate technical advice to overcome obstacles specific to your project and your level of experience.

Integration with The Chromatic Voice \(taught on Monday mornings\): This course is the essential practical partner, ensuring that both foundational knowledge and advanced conceptual exploration are successfully translated into realized, high-quality paintings. Prerequisite: Students must have completed at least one introductory course in oil painting or demonstrate equivalent foundational knowledge \(e.g., knowledge of basic setup, brush cleaning, and layering principles\).

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

title: Sashiko Mending
description:
Schedule

Thursday, February 19, 2026 5:30 PM ‚Äì 8:00 PM

Experience Level

Beginning

Event Category: Fiber Arts

Age\(s\)

13\+

Children under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult.

$50 ‚Äì Registration Cost $10 ‚Äì Materials Fee $60 ‚Äì Total Registration CostLearn Sashiko mending: patch, reinforce, and decorate garments with traditional Japanese stitching. Practice on your clothes or provided fabric.

What you‚Äôll do

This class introduces the technique of Sashiko mending. With humble beginnings in rural Japan, Sashiko‚Äôs running stitch insulated work garments for warmth and longevity. Learn how to patch and repair a rip or hole, reinforce a worn area, and prepare distressed textile in order to draw a Sashiko grid and stitch a pattern. Choose from a variety of traditional Sashiko patterns. Bring in one or two garments to assess for mending or decorating. Medium-weight, woven fabrics work best; such as denim, cotton or linen. If desired, students may simply practice a Sashiko pattern or two on sampler patches provided. All supplies are provided \(thread, needles, thimble, fabric to practice on, chalk, patterns, scraps to use as patches\). Students will take home their two needles, twenty-two yards of cotton Sashiko thread, and a Sashiko thimble.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

location: The Unstruck Drum - Center for Shamanism
description:
This monthly gathering meets every third Thursday of each month. We have the intention of offering a safe space for all men who walk a path of seeking authenticity. Led by Collin Hoctor, this group brings community, shares wisdom, and brings healing to those who desire to walk a deeper, more meaningful life.

From Collin:

I am a psychotherapist and guide whose work weaves together spirituality, nature-based practices, psychedelic therapy, and recovery. My path has been shaped by a foundation in existential philosophy and psychology, medicine circles, and a lifelong study of contemplative and esoteric traditions. Out of my own longing for community and a commitment to the needs of the moment, I am passionate about creating spaces for men to gather in honesty, vulnerability, and authenticity ‚Äî places where we can face our struggles, share our truths, and remember the healing power of connection.

title: Napa Bookmine Book Club: Colored Television by Danzy Senna
description: Join us for a book club discussion! This year, 2026, Napa Bookmine Book Clubs' book picks will come straight from home, this year's Napa Bookmine BINGO Card! Each book will match a BINGO square. Hurrah! Play along with Napa Bookmine and read some new, fun books, and if you come to every meeting, you may get a BINGO in the meantime. ;\) This month, we'll be talking about Danzy Senna's Colored Television. This is a free event, but we would appreciate your RSVP so we can plan for your attendance! Questions? Email us at events@napabookmine.com ABOUT THE BOOK A NATIONAL BESTSELLER | A GOOD MORNING AMERICA BOOK CLUB PICK | A WASHINGTON POST TOP 10 BOOK OF THE YEAR | A NEW YORK TIMES NOTABLE BOOK OF 2024 ‚ÄúA laugh-out-loud cultural comedy‚Ä¶ This is the New Great American Novel, and Danzy Senna has set the standard.‚Äù ‚ÄìLA Times ‚ÄúFunny, foxy and fleet‚Ä¶The jokes are good, the punches land, the dialogue is tart.‚Äù ‚Äì Dwight Garner, The New York Times A brilliant take on love and ambition, failure and reinvention, and the racial-identity-industrial complex from the bestselling author of Caucasia. Jane has high hopes that her life is about to turn around. After a long, precarious stretch bouncing among sketchy rentals and sublets, she and her family are living in luxury for a year, house-sitting in the hills above Los Angeles. The gig magically coincides with Jane‚Äôs sabbatical, giving her the time and space she needs to finish her second novel‚Äîa centuries-spanning epic her artist husband, Lenny, dubs her ‚Äúmulatto War and Peace.‚Äù Finally, some semblance of stability and success seems to be within her grasp. But things don‚Äôt work out quite as hoped. Desperate for a plan B, like countless writers before her Jane turns her gaze to Hollywood. When she finagles a meeting with Hampton Ford, a hot producer with a major development deal at a streaming network, he seems excited to work with a ‚Äúreal writer,‚Äù and together they begin to develop ‚Äúthe Jackie Robinson of biracial comedies.‚Äù Things finally seem to be going right for Jane‚Äîuntil they go terribly wrong. Funny, piercing, and page turning, Colored Television is Senna‚Äôs most on-the-pulse, ambitious, and rewarding novel yet. ABOUT THE AUTHOR Danzy Senna is the author of four previous works of fiction, including the bestselling Caucasia and, most recently, New People, as well as a memoir. The recipient of numerous awards and honors, she teaches writing at the University of Southern California.

title: Profs & Pints Napa: The (New) Science of Attraction
description:
Profs and Pints Napa¬†presents:¬†‚ÄúThe \(New\) Science of Attraction,‚Äù¬†on psychological research that‚Äôs upending assumptions about how we pick partners, with Paul W. Eastwick, professor of psychology at the University of California Davis and author of¬†Bonded by Evolution: The New Science of Love and Connection.

Over the past few decades, a buzzy new branch of science, evolutionary psychology, has spread a deeply flawed story about romantic relationships. Cloaking itself in the language of incontrovertible Darwinian fact, it has popularized the idea that our minds have been shaped by primal drives that pit the genders against each other. It has promoted the myth that men are wired to be promiscuous and the notions that wealth, status, and beauty are the ultimate aphrodisiacs.

It‚Äôs time to say goodbye to such thinking and embrace a more-evolved view of romance, argues Paul W. Eastwick, who co-hosts the¬†Love Factually podcast and operates a UC-Davis research lab that studies attraction and relationships.

Come to Napa Yards for a talk by Dr. Eastwick that will give you a much more sophisticated understanding of matters of the heart.¬†

Drawing from pathbreaking research‚Äîincluding original experiments from his own lab‚Äîhe‚Äôll offer the take that relationship success hinges on compatibility rather than finding someone who meets some universal ideal of a good partner.

He‚Äôll show that while popularity factors into first impressions, its influence fades fast. When evaluating mutual friends and acquaintances they‚Äôve known for months, single people barely agree in their ratings of who is or isn‚Äôt desirable as a dating partner.

Although men and women occasionally say they want different things out of romance, gender differences evaporate once we assess what men and women actually want. Attraction from ancestral times through the present is best depicted as a process of finding‚Äîand, often, creating‚Äîa compatible relationship.

Dr. Eastwick will show how the traits we often look for in a partner‚Äîpersonality, lifestyle, values, and humor‚Äîare poor predictors of compatibility. Instead, lasting attraction is built through the gradual forging of strong attachment bonds, through mundane moments in which people offer each other a ‚Äúsafe haven‚Äù and ‚Äúsecure base.‚Äù

Distilling evolutionary biology, anthropology, and psychology into accessible insights, he‚Äôll explain why we so often choose dating strategies that make us miserable and how we can use a more evolved approach. \(Tickets available only online. Advance tickets: $13.50 plus processing fees. Doors: $17, or $15 with a student ID. Doors open at 5:30 and the talk begins at 6:30.\)

Image: ‚ÄúLove Match,‚Äù by Jan van Beers \(Wikimedia Commons\).

title: Alibi Bookshop February Book Club: The Heaven and Earth Grocery Store by James McBride
description: NOTE: THIS IS THE 3RD THURSDAY DUE TO SCHEDULING CONFLICTS  Please join us on Thursday, February 19th at 7pm to discuss ‚ÄúThe Heaven and Earth Grocery Store‚Äù by James McBride! THE RUNAWAY NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER A NEW YORK TIMES NOTABLE BOOK ‚Ä¢ A NEW YORK TIMES READERS PICK: 100 BEST BOOKS OF THE 21ST CENTURY WINNER OF THE 2024 LIBRARY OF CONGRESS PRIZE FOR AMERICAN FICTION FROM ONE OF TIME MAGAZINE‚ÄôS 100 MOST INFLUENTIAL PEOPLE OF 2024 NAMED A BEST BOOK OF THE YEAR BY NPR/FRESH AIR, WASHINGTON POST, THE NEW YORKER, AND TIME MAGAZINE ONE OF BARACK OBAMA‚ÄôS FAVORITE BOOKS OF 2023 ‚ÄúA murder mystery locked inside a Great American Novel . . . Charming, smart, heart-blistering, and heart-healing.‚Äù ‚ÄîDanez Smith, The New York Times Book Review ‚ÄúWe all need‚Äîwe all deserve‚Äîthis vibrant, love-affirming novel that bounds over any difference that claims to separate us.‚Äù ‚ÄîRon Charles, The Washington Post In 1972, when workers in Pottstown, Pennsylvania, were digging the foundations for a new development, the last thing they expected to find was a skeleton at the bottom of a well. Who the skeleton was and how it got there were two of the long-held secrets kept by the residents of Chicken Hill, the dilapidated neighborhood where immigrant Jews and African Americans lived side by side and shared ambitions and sorrows. Chicken Hill was where Moshe and Chona Ludlow lived when Moshe integrated his theater and where Chona ran the Heaven & Earth Grocery Store. When the state came looking for a deaf boy to institutionalize him, it was Chona and Nate Timblin, the Black janitor at Moshe‚Äôs theater and the unofficial leader of the Black community on Chicken Hill, who worked together to keep the boy safe. As these characters‚Äô stories overlap and deepen, it becomes clear how much the people who live on the margins of white, Christian America struggle and what they must do to survive. When the truth is finally revealed about what happened on Chicken Hill and the part the town‚Äôs white establishment played in it, McBride shows us that even in dark times, it is love and community‚Äîheaven and earth‚Äîthat sustain us. Books are available in the shop, online and ebooks at bookshop.org/shop/alibibookshop and audio: libro.fm/alibibookshop

title: Mama's Broke
description:
Mama‚Äôs Broke is a powerful folk duo that deliver a compelling performance with heart and raw energy. Although highly influenced by their Canadian roots, Lisa and Amy are based out of nowhere and everywhere. 

Their two strong voices blend to create haunting harmonies, while they artfully juggle fiddle, banjo, guitar and mandolin, and incorporate traditional dance and foot percussion into their performance. Their original ‚Äì and often dark ‚Äì compositions push the boundaries of tradition and the constraints of genre. Drawing from old-time, Quebecois, blues, punk, Celtic, Balkan and  doom metal, they create a soundscape that is both familiar and new. 

Since forming the band in 2014, Mama‚Äôs Broke has been gaining momentum fast ; having already completed two European, and several Canadian and U.S. tours. They have performed in a wide range of venues, from circus shows in New Orleans, to pirate ships in Amsterdam, to concert halls in Ireland, to theatres in Brooklyn. In this way, they stay true to the transient nature of folklore, as they travel the world sharing and collecting song.

title: The Sam Chase & Willy Tea Taylor at Hopmonk Sebastopol
location: HopMonk Tavern ‚Äì Sebastopol, 230 Petaluma Ave, Sebastopol, CA
description:
ABOUT: 
THE SAM CHASE: 
The Sam Chase is a natural storyteller with a voice that sounds as if it has weathered many an epic tale. With boot stomping orchestration and lyrics that have been immortalized on the tattooed skin of their fans, The Sam Chase & his band, The Untraditional, don‚Äôt mess around. 
WILLY TEA TAYLOR: 
There is no question that Willy Tea Taylor‚Äôs life as a singer/songwriter was predetermined ‚Äì his role realized the moment he wrote his first song. His inspirations drawn from two separate wells; Living the life of a cattleman‚Äôs kid and experiencing true visionaries music like Greg Brown, John Hartford, and Guy Clark. The image of Guy Clark and friends sitting around the kitchen table loaded with ashtrays full of butts, half-smoked cigarettes, food, and booze on one Christmas Eve in 1975 burned into Taylors‚Äôs soul. Those guys, swapping songs without pretense, lit Willy Tea‚Äôs fire. And ever since, its led purpose with passion ‚Äì finding a hang by curating relationships through musical friendships that get him closer to his own Clark style kitchen table. 
From his early days co-fronting The Good Luck Thrift Store Outfit, to singing solo in countless cowboy bars, to pitching countless wiffle ball games, Willy Tea has never lost the vision. Now Willy Tea Taylor has taken his vision of the ‚Äúhero hang‚Äù on the road. and his talented traveling band The Fellership is made up of his fantastically talented buds who play Willy‚Äôs songs with a brand of reckless abandon and utter humility that spits in the face of pretense. The way The Fellership plays Will‚Äôs songs is the way they demand to be played and, in their short time together, they have been awe-ing every audience lucky enough to see them.

title: Cheese & Butter Classes
description:
Join award-winning cheesemaker Sheana Davis and wine expert Ben Sessions for unforgettable¬†cheese and butter making classes. Perfect for team building, celebrations, and educational events, our classes are interactive, fun, and easy for everyone. 

From classes on how to make Creme de Ricotta wheel to Mozzarella Pulling to butter-making classes, guests will always leave with a creamy treat to take home \(if it makes it that far!\) ‚Äì so bring a small cooler with you.¬† 

Food has a remarkable ability to bring people together. 

Cheesemaking classes are perfect for team-building activities, company meetings, team celebrations, staff events, corporate fun, bridal parties, couples classes, girlfriend getaway weekends, LGBT events, EBT education courses, and more. Classes held year-round on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, 12:00-2:00 and 3:30-5:30pm. 

See the full schedule of all our cheese and butter making classes here.¬† 

With each class, we give back to the community by providing meals for food-insecure seniors in Sonoma Valley. After learning how to make cheese, our guests can prepare these meals and write personal notes for the seniors on the lids.¬† 

Join us in making a positive impact while having fun and learning a new skill.¬†¬† 

Your Cheesemaking Experience: 



Begin with local wine and an artisanal cheese tasting.

Learn to make cheese and compound butter with everyday ingredients and tools.

Enjoy specialized classes for dishes like lasagna and gourmet grilled cheeses.

Exclusive guest cheesemakers often share their techniques.

Ideal for corporate events, bridal parties, getaways, and more.



Sheana and Ben pride themselves on using ingredients readily available in any local grocery store, with cooking supplies used reside in most home cooks‚Äô kitchens. Guest cheesemakers are often available to showcase their own cheeses and techniques, making the class a truly unique experience. 

Check the schedule for¬†Wine Country-based cheesemaking classes.¬† 

Customize Your Class:To arrange private or corporate classes at venues like Sonoma Fairmont Mission Inn or Silverado Resort, contact us at¬†sheanadavis@gmail.com. We can help create a unique and unforgettable experience for your entire group! Private and corporate classes may be arranged and are hosted at various Wine Country venues, including The Fairmont Sonoma Mission Inn, Silverado Resort, The Lodge in Sonoma, and private homes and estates. 

To register: 

https://theepicureanconnection.com/events/

title: 11th Annual Farmers' Convergence
location: University of California Hopland Research and Extension Center
description:
The School of Adaptive Agriculture invites you to the 11th Annual Farmers‚Äô Convergence on February 21, 2026, at the UC Hopland Research & Extension Center in Hopland, CA. 

This beloved farmer-to-farmer gathering is entering an exciting new chapter. After a decade of grassroots success, the Farmers‚Äô Convergence is expanding to UC Hopland REC, marking a significant evolution that bridges lived farming experience with deep ecological practices. This partnership represents a deeper commitment to regenerative land stewardship and our local food economy. 

The event will bring together farmers, gardeners, schools and food activists, from beginners to seasoned veterans, conventional to experimental, for innovative solutions, knowledge exchange, and forward-thinking strategies. Together, we‚Äôll explore soil regeneration, biodiversity, systems thinking, and economic sustainability while renewing our collective inspiration and momentum. It will include events the day before, and after. 

Everyone belongs in this conversation. Tickets are limited, so don‚Äôt delay. We hope you will join us as we champion collaborative progress and expanded possibility. 

Learn more: www.schoolofadaptiveagriculture.org/convergence

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

A class that is all about pinching! With instructor Dan, students will learn handbuilding methods to coil and pitch their vessels. With specific direction in learning the techniques to build any size of pot, from a large scale vessel to a small cup. title: Introduction to the Art of Bookmaking
description:
Schedule

Fridays, February 20 ‚Äì March 13, 2026 10:00 AM ‚Äì 1:00 PM

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Categories: Fiber Arts, Other, Printmaking

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$220 ‚Äì Registration Cost $30 ‚Äì Materials Fee $250 ‚Äì Total Registration CostLearn essential bookbinding techniques in this 4-week introduction to book arts. Create zines, pamphlets, accordion folds, and more using traditional paper-folding and stitching methods.

What you‚Äôll do

Join guest artist, Bettina Pauly in this incredible introduction to book arts! The art of bookmaking, otherwise known as bookbinding, is the physical craft of creating an artistic book from start to finish. In this introductory 4-session class, you will learn the basic use of bookbinding tools and materials, along with simple bookbinding structures that utilize paper softcovers. Students will learn several basic bookbinding structures and stitches that every beginning book artist should know! Experience technical skills such as paper folding, cutting, sewing and gluing, mixed with artistic elements of design to create functional, elegant objects built for storytelling. The instructor will offer guided instruction in a supportive learning environment with a limited class size. Each 3-hour session will meet for four consecutive weeks and focus on the following core bookbinding techniques:

Session 1: Intro to tools and paper folding; one sheet wonder zine, ‚Äòpants‚Äô fold with and without cover, map folds

Session 2: Pamphlets, and Japanese stab hole binding; three hole pamphlet stitch, five hole pamphlet stitch, Japanese stab binding two holes / five holes¬†

Session 3: Accordion folds; accordion fold, accordion fold tipped into envelope cover, accordion fold with non-adhesive cover

Session 4: Magic wallets, and personal projects

The class materials fee will include paper and all the tools needed to create each of these projects. Students will be able to take home all of their book projects at the end of the workshop. Please note: This class requires some hand dexterity to maneuver bookbinding tools. Participants should feel comfortable using tools with sharp edges such as an awl, x-acto knife, and scissors.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9‚ÄìMarch 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of¬†bonsai and the season‚Äôs first flowers.¬†Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year‚Äôs all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai‚Äîtrees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot¬†bonsai¬†take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal‚Äîreminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from¬†hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through¬†Hanami Strolls‚Äîguided walks through the Garden‚Äôs Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

description:
Discover the joy of Watercolor Painting!

Unlock your creativity with our Beginning Watercolor Class, designed for beginners and advanced beginners alike! Dive into the vibrant world of watercolor and master the techniques to create stunning artwork.





Course Details:

  * Instructor: Eva Mautner
  * Fee: $60 per class or $220 for 4 classes
  * Days & Times: Wednesdays & Fridays, 10:30 AM - 12:30 PM

  * Master the ‚Äòwet on wet‚Äô watercolor technique

  * Build confidence and find joy in the creative process
  * Create and label a swatch of colors

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit:  Color of Love
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE¬† 1/15/26

**FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE**

EXHIBIT DATES:¬† January 26 ‚Äì February 22, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 ‚Äì 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery‚Äôs free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.¬† Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artists, **Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich** present the **Color of Love,** paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.¬† Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.¬† In Gray‚Äôs ‚ÄúLove Abstractly‚Äù an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color. ¬†Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her ‚ÄúBowl of Strawberries,‚Äù ¬†fruit rendered so realistically, one‚Äôs mouth waters. ¬†Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays ‚Äì tulips and scarlet buglers.¬† Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta‚Äôs jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in ‚ÄúRaven Heart‚Äù and Rapp‚Äôs little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in ‚ÄúFoxy Flowers.‚Äù¬† Shore‚Äôs ‚ÄúShowering You with Gifts‚Äù catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.¬† ‚ÄúAs we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine‚Äôs Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,‚Äù noted Gray.¬† ¬†

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Laura Roney‚Äôs Dance!,** a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.¬† And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.¬† In ‚ÄúHold Me Tight‚Äù one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine‚Äôs Day.¬† Another couple joyfully whoops it up in ‚ÄúBust a Move.‚Äù Bring on the music ‚Äì these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am ‚Äì 6 pm.¬†¬†¬† **www.upstairsart gallery.net**

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

description: For the Love of Art February 5 - March 2, 2026 Arts Guild of Sonoma | 140 East Napa Street, Sonoma Celebrate creativity and Valentine's Day this February with For the Love of Art, a special exhibition at the Arts Guild of Sonoma.
