title: Bone by Bone - Lecture
description: Bone by Bone: The Commingled Remains from theTomb at Tell Abraq, UAE (2200-2000 BC)  The tomb at the archaeological site of Tell Abraq, located near modern-day Abu Dhabi and Dubai, was discovered in 1989 and excavated over several field seasons. Over 300 individuals were placed in the tomb including premature and newborn infants, toddlers, teens, and adult males and females of all ages. Over time,the addition of corpses caused the disarticulation of most all of the skeletal remains. Our analysis proceeded on a bone by bone basis and questions about health and disease, trauma and violence, and diet and nutrition were addressed using innovative methods for skeletal analysis. "Osteobiographies" were created that provide a glimpse into what life was like over 4000 years ago in in the deserts of Arabia. And, one very enigmatic teenager, the only individual whose remains were not commingled, and perhaps the last person to be put in the tomb, provides a poignant reminder of the toll that disease takes.Event Details    Sunday, February 22nd from 4-5 pm    SRJC Petaluma Student Center in Mike Smith Hall    Debra L. Martin, Distinguished Professor Emerita of Anthropology at the University of Nevada in Las Vegas, is an expert on violence in past societies, which includes expertise in human osteology and bioarchaeology. She received her PhD from the University of Massachusetts. The analysis of skeletonized human remains from archaeological as well as historic and contemporary settings form a basis for understanding the effects of trauma, fractures, disability and wounds related to lethal and nonlethal violence. She is the Series Editor for Bioarchaeology and Social Theory, a book series dedicated to cutting-edge bioarchaeological work published by Springer Verlag. She is also the Editor of the journal, American Antiquity. Her recent publications include co-authoring Gender Violence in the American Southwest (AD 1100) (Routledge), co-editing Bioarchaeology of Borders and Frontiers (UPF), Massacres (UPF), and Bioarchaeological and Forensic Perspectives on Violence (Cambridge). She is co-author of the textbook, Bioarchaeology An Integrated Approach to Working with Human Remains.

title: Overeaters Anonymous (OA) Newcomer Meeting in Santa Rosa
description:
**Is Food a Problem for You? You Are Not Alone.**

Overeaters Anonymous (OA) is a fellowship of people who support each other in recovering from compulsive eating and food behaviors. If you feel you have a problem with food, OA welcomes you‚Äîno matter what your background, beliefs, or eating habits.

We hold an in-person newcomer meeting on **Sundays from 4:00 ‚Äì 5:00 PM** **at Christ Church United Methodist, 1717 Yulupa Ave., Room #4, Santa Rosa**. Contact: Abigail (707) 293-5888. You may view all North Bay OA in-person and online meetings at https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html .

In OA, members experience **spiritual, emotional, and physical recovery** by practicing the **Twelve Steps** and living by their spiritual principles‚Äîone day at a time.

OA is **not** a diet club or calorie-counting program.

Members have different plans of eating.

OA does **not** endorse any specific food plan.

If food is causing problems in your life, you don‚Äôt have to struggle alone. Recovery is possible, and help is available.

**Visit:** https://www.northbayoa.org/

**Find a meeting:** https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html

The show is No Cover, so please Tip What You Can to support local comedy : \)

At Non-Toxic Comedy Show‚Ñ¢ you‚Äôll get all the jokes with none of the trauma!

NTCS‚Ñ¢ guarantees our audience CLEAN, NON-TOXIC comedy without having to worry about inappropriate, offensive, cringeworthy content. Our CLEAN SHOW at Redwood Cafe, Cotati, is safe for all ages, genders, and levels of sensitivity.

Don‚Äôt get us wrong ‚Äì a great set always runs the risk of offending someone. Who could‚Äôve known it really was too soon, just for them?

But there are some things we here at Non-Toxic Comedy Show‚Ñ¢ think are always too soon and will never age well. At NTCS you'll never hear anything hateful or malicious , or jokes that punch down. Plus we keep things PG clean!

Respectful innuendo is just funnier. The writing is hard, the material is smart, the laughter is real. That's the toxic-free guarantee! We guarantee our audience Non-Toxic, family-safe comedy.

While we trust our performers to adhere to these guidelines, if a joke seems like it's about to cross the line, the performer will be cut off with a cowbell, and may not be invited back. Our goal at Non-Toxic Comedy Show‚Ñ¢? No Cowbell!

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

Advance your oil painting skills in a supportive, solvent-free studio while exploring color,light, and challenging subjects to deepen technique and expression.

What you‚Äôll do

This 8-week course is designed for artists ready to deepen their technical skills and personal expression in a calm, supportive, and solvent-free studio. It serves as the natural continuation of the Fall 2025 course ‚ÄúPalette & Possibility,‚Äù and is also open to experienced oil painters who wish to advance their practice within a framework focused on cognitive stimulation and emotional well-being. We will move beyond simple objects to tackle subjects that introduce new cognitive challenges, such as atmosphere, reflective surfaces, and simplified portrait elements. Emphasis remains on process over product, nurturing focus, spatial reasoning, and emotional insight. Through an explorative journey into composition, light, and ‚ÄúThe Chromatic Voice‚Äù‚Äîyour unique use of color‚Äî students will strengthen their artistic voices while continuing to reap the rewards of enhanced mental agility and profound emotional well-being.

Optional Materials Packet & Supply List

$35 includes all necessary paints, mediums, brushes, surfaces \(canvas panels\), and cleaning supplies for the 8 weeks. Students who wish to bring their own materials should view the supply list. You can view the full supply list here.

Membership has its benefits

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9‚ÄìMarch 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of¬†bonsai and the season‚Äôs first flowers.¬†Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year‚Äôs all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai‚Äîtrees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot¬†bonsai¬†take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal‚Äîreminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from¬†hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through¬†Hanami Strolls‚Äîguided walks through the Garden‚Äôs Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE¬† 2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:¬† February 23 ‚Äì March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery‚Äôs free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.¬† Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women‚Äôs History Month. Shore‚Äôs watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.¬† These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.¬† A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in ‚ÄúGood Point.‚Äù¬† The artist takes us into nature with ‚ÄúRedwood Rendezvous‚Äù where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.¬†¬† ¬†‚ÄúJust Back from Vegas‚Äù captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.¬† ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic ‚Äì women deserve nothing less,‚Äù noted Shore.¬†

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

¬†The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer‚Äôs Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.¬† Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with ‚Äúla belle vie.‚Äù The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in ‚ÄúCaf√© le Bistro‚Äù, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.¬† One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer‚Äôs unique view of the Eiffel Tower in ‚ÄúParis is for Lovers.‚Äù ‚ÄúEvery day was an adventure in Paris ‚Äì I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there‚Äù, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am ‚Äì 6 pm.¬†¬†¬† **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our¬†Beginner Tap Dance¬†class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years! This class introduces students to the fundamentals of tap dance while fostering rhythm, coordination, and confidence in a fun and supportive environment. Dancers will learn foundational steps such as shuffles, flaps, and cramp rolls, building towards simple combinations and routines. Through engaging exercises and dynamic music, students will develop timing, musicality, and precision. Perfect for beginners or those with some experience, this class encourages creativity and self-expression while building essential dance skills. Step into the world of tap and let the rhythm move you! No prior experience required‚Äîjust bring your tap shoes and enthusiasm to dance! Recital on Saturday, March 21st. More info on recital soon.

Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off¬†face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Whether your child is a first-time dancer or loves to move to the beat, Tiny Tappers is the perfect way to develop musicality, motor skills, and a love for dance. Tap into the fun and watch your little one shine! No experience is necessary ‚Äì just bring your tap shoes and a smile! Recital on Saturday, March 21st. More info on recital soon.

Required Supply List

Tap shoes of any color and style,¬†Comfortable clothing to move in¬†or dance-wear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off¬†face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Being dressed and ready for class is part of the experience and encourages focus and participation. You can find tap shoes at¬†Discount Dance Supply¬†, Amazon,¬†Capezio, and¬†Bloch¬†and sometimes Target for Kid‚Äôs sizes.¬†Any color and style will do. Not necessary for the first class, may wear hard soled shoes.

title: Tidepool Volunteer Orientation
description:
This is a two-part training 

The tidepools on the Sonoma Coast State Park beaches are teeming with multitudes of flora and fauna. From virtually invisible colonies of aggregating anemones to sea stars tucked under kelp, there are fragile intertidal creatures everywhere.

Tidepool education volunteers teach school and adult groups how to safely observe and interact with the fascinating life forms of the intertidal zone. Participants learn about the importance of protecting the fragile plants and animals that inhabit this special ecosystem. Tidepool Roving volunteers stationed on beaches during low tides provide park visitors with a safe and educational experience exploring the tidepools. Additionally, docents provide interpretation when our Touch Table is featured at events or along the coast.

No experience necessary! As a new volunteer, you will shadow experienced volunteers until you feel comfortable on your own.

We look forward to seeing you on¬†Monday February 23 for part one of our two-part training

Part 1 of the training: Monday February 23 ¬†6 ‚Äì 8pm on zoom

Part 2 of the training:¬†Field Visit Sunday March 1 from¬†3 ‚Äì 5 PM at Campbell Cove, Bodega¬†Head, Sonoma Coast State Park¬†Map to Campbell Cove

title: Please join us to hear photographer Phil Venable present travelogue photos
description:
February speaker, Phil Venable, has been shooting photos since he was a kid, when his dad gave him a Kodak Brownie. He studied black-and-white photography in college and had plans to be a photojournalist until life intervened. After spending an adulthood in law enforcement, Phil picked up his camera again and began making art.¬† Phil‚Äôs preference is nature/landscape, but he is drawn to shapes, lines, and shadows found in urban landscapes. ‚ÄúMy favorite subjects are old rusted cars, trains, abandoned buildings, and brightly colored doors. ¬†I use several plugins in Photoshop to create surreal images from otherwise ordinary photos. ¬†I create photos in both color and black and white, depending on subject matter and mood.‚Äù

Phil is President of the Napa Valley Photographic Society, and a member of the Fairfield Suisun Valley Art Association, the Vacaville Art League, Gold Rush Photo Club, and the Lightwriters Photography Club. ¬†Phil is also a member of the Professional Photographers of America, and the Photographic Society of America.

Phil‚Äôs work has been shown at Viewpoint Gallery, Sacramento; Yountville Community Center, The Old Sugar Mill, Arata Fine Arts Gallery, and the Roseville Brewing Company, including shows at the Vacaville Art Gallery, the Napa Public Library, Solano Town Center Gallery, the Gallery at Village 360, and he is a resident artist at The Little Shop in Benicia. ¬†He has won several awards at local shows and contests, including a Juror's Choice Award at the 2013 Vacaville Art Gallery Juried Art Show.¬† Phil‚Äôs photos can be seen at www.philipvenablephotography.com. ¬†He is also on Facebook as Philip Venable Photography. ¬†Contact Phil at philven@comcast.net.

Napa Valley Photographic Society \(NVPS\) promotes the art and science of photography, providing education, image appreciation, inspiration, exchange of technologies. Most months we invite guest speakers to evaluate our images.¬† Guests are welcome to attend.¬† Check the website for more information http://www.napavalleyphotographicsociety.org.

title: Santa Rosa Symphony - Mahler's Third
description: Mahler's Third February 21, 22 & 23, 2026 Weill Hall, Green Music Center Francesco Lecce-Chong, conductor Gabrielle Beteag, mezzo-soprano Treble Voices of the SSU Symphonic Chorus, Jenny Bent, director Gustav Mahler: Symphony No. 3 in D minor Mahler's Third Symphony explores the human condition, nature, and the divine. With six movements, it reflects Mahler's philosophical quest to "embrace everything." Mezzo-soprano Gabrielle Beteag and the Treble Voices of the SSU Symphonic Chorus, directed by Jenny Bent, return to Weill Hall to perform what is regarded as one of the greatest symphonies of all time. title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9‚ÄìMarch 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of¬†bonsai and the season‚Äôs first flowers.¬†Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year‚Äôs all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai‚Äîtrees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot¬†bonsai¬†take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal‚Äîreminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from¬†hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through¬†Hanami Strolls‚Äîguided walks through the Garden‚Äôs Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

title: Watercolor Fundamentals Part 1
location: Rileystreet Art Supply,103 Maxwell Ct, Santa Rosa, CA 95401, USA
description:
Instructor: Anne Millett

This is a 6-class series, meeting 6 Tuesdays
10:30AM-1:00PM
Location: Santa Rosa Store
$270.00


*Additional: Separate $20.00 plus tax Materials Fee paid to Anne at the first class, for the high-quality Arches #140 cold press watercolor paper. Brushes, palettes, high-quality watercolor paint, and set-ups for use during class will be provided.*

There will be a materials fee of $15 plus tax for the series.


Watercolor Fundamentals - Part 1

This class focuses on the simple delight of mixing color with water, brushing it on paper, and watching what happens as it moves and dries. You will learn easy ways to create paintings that are all about color and the sometimes unpredictable nature of water.

No drawing skills are needed.

In this class we will explore the basic principles of watercolor painting. Learn or refresh your understanding of brush handling, brush care and setting up, the benefits of ‚Äúgood paper‚Äù, watercolor lights and darks, flat and graded washes, wet-on-wet techniques such as charging, wet-on-dry techniques such as glazing, color wheel, color theory, color mixing, and more. Simple applications of these techniques invite you to experiment and play.

This class is designed for adults 18+

$270 for 6 classes, 2.5 hours each class
Payable via check, cash, or Zelle.

*Brushes, palettes, set-ups, and paint will be provided.*


To see Anne's work and to learn more about this class, please visit her website at: http://www.miraaster.com https://www.miraaster.com/ www.miraaster.com

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE¬† 2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:¬† February 23 ‚Äì March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery‚Äôs free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.¬† Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women‚Äôs History Month. Shore‚Äôs watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.¬† These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.¬† A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in ‚ÄúGood Point.‚Äù¬† The artist takes us into nature with ‚ÄúRedwood Rendezvous‚Äù where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.¬†¬† ¬†‚ÄúJust Back from Vegas‚Äù captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.¬† ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic ‚Äì women deserve nothing less,‚Äù noted Shore.¬†

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

¬†The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer‚Äôs Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.¬† Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with ‚Äúla belle vie.‚Äù The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in ‚ÄúCaf√© le Bistro‚Äù, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.¬† One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer‚Äôs unique view of the Eiffel Tower in ‚ÄúParis is for Lovers.‚Äù ‚ÄúEvery day was an adventure in Paris ‚Äì I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there‚Äù, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am ‚Äì 6 pm.¬†¬†¬† **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

title: Author Talks: Smithson's Gamble: The History Behind the World's Largest Museum
description: Register here: Follow the fascinating growth and development of the world's largest museum and research complex during its first 60 years. location: Rileystreet Art Supply,103 Maxwell Ct, Santa Rosa, CA 95401, USA
description:
Instructor: Anne Millett

This is a 6-class series, meeting 6 Tuesday afternoons

6 Tuesday afternoons, 2:00PM - 4:30PM

January 20, 27, February 3, 10, 17, 24

$270.00

*Additional: Separate $20.00 plus tax Materials Fee paid to Anne at the first class, for the high-quality Arches #140 cold press watercolor paper. Brushes, palettes, high-quality watercolor paint, and set-ups for use during class will be provided.*


Watercolor Fundamentals Part 3

You‚Äôve experienced Part 1, you‚Äôve experienced Part 2, and now let‚Äôs dive into more water in Part 3! More water leads to more spontaneity and deepens our focus in the moment. Loose florals, imagined landscapes, and abstractions are painted wet-into-wet style in multiple layers. Refining our abilities to work with the water keeps us open to possibilities and surprises in our paintings as they emerge.

This class is designed for adults 18+

$270 for 6 classes, 2.5 hours each class
Payable via check, cash, or Zelle.

description:
Every Tuesday 3:30 PM ‚Äì 5:30 PM

Age\(s\)

Children will be inspired by a different artist each month and create 3D sculptural worlds from their own conceptualized 2D drawings.

What you‚Äôll do

In this imaginative, hands-on art class, young artists will explore the magical worlds of beloved artists & illustrators. Each month they will learn about a different artist: ¬†Phoebe Wahl \(January\), Antje Damm \(February\),¬†Karen Collins \(March\), Richard Scary \(April\), and Hayao Miyazaki \(May\)¬†. Inspired by their playful styles, students will¬†design and develop their very own characters‚Äîdeciding where these characters¬†live, work, play, eat, and sleep!¬†Students will be working independently as well as in groups to develop their visual storytelling muscles.¬† Children will create 3D sculptural worlds from their conceptualized 2D drawings. They will bring their stories to life using a mix of expressive art materials, including:

¬†watercolor, paint, pens,¬†and¬†collage

¬†recycled and found objects to build unique scenes

Together, we will learn:

How to use¬†watercolor techniques¬†to add color and mood

How¬†scale¬†helps characters and environments feel real

The¬†arc of a story‚Äîbeginning, middle, and end

How to build a world using¬†background, middle ground, and foreground

By the end of the class, each child will have created their own illustrated story scene full of imagination, personality, and creativity. A perfect class for kids who love drawing, storytelling, and building new worlds!

class descriptionAdventure Gaming classes presented by The Game Academy are held weekly for¬†2-hour sessions over an 8-week term.¬†Participating players explore collaborative storytelling in a mentorship model using¬†games like Dungeons & Dragons to build community, foster¬†empathy, and support social-emotional growth. Our trained Educator-Gamemasters guide players in choosing the kinds of stories that interest them, then support unique and dynamic character creation, and finally¬†present an engaging narrative filled with puzzles and mysteries to be solved, social role-play to navigate, and¬†tactical challenges to be overcome‚Ä¶ all based on the players‚Äô interests.¬†This uniquely tailored experience¬†provides a rich context of personal investment, and engages our players with a fun and collaborative activity that helps them overcome social and emotional challenges, teaches them to engage with a growth mindset, supports the development of critical thinking and cooperative problem-solving skills, and helps them form lasting bonds with their peers. title: Intermediate Salsa Class
description:
This class is designed for dancers who have a solid grasp of the basics and are eager to expand their repertoire with more complex and fluid movements.

Pre- requisite:

Salsa Class Beginners

Each week, we‚Äôll break down a new move, focusing on the technique and connection that will make you a more confident and stylish dancer. We‚Äôll go beyond the foundational steps to cover a wide range of essential intermediate patterns and styling, including:

Turns and Spins:

Master your inside and outside turns, double spins, and the elegant 360 and Hand Toss moves.

Intricate Patterns:

Learn to execute the 360, wrap, as well as various Cross Body Lead variations like the U-Turn and Spiral.

Footwork and Styling:

Enhance your rhythm and flair with advanced footwork like the Suzy Q, Front Tap, and Mambo Step. We‚Äôll also work on styling with a wrap and improving your posture and upper body movement.

This class is your chance to refine your technique, improve your lead-follow connection, and add a variety of fun and dynamic moves to your salsa vocabulary. Join us and elevate your dance!

Details:

No partner necessary ‚Äî rotations ensure everyone gets to dance.

Please wear¬†non-marking shoe soles¬†to protect the floor.

Arrive 10 minutes early to warm up and get settled.

title: Jewish Course in Novato Explores Dreams, Astrology, and the Evil Eye
description:
NOVATO, CA¬†‚Äî Chabad Jewish Center of Novato is launching a new fascinating 4 week class:¬†Jewpernatural: Signs, Spirits, and Superstition in Jewish Belief, a new four-week course from the beginning¬†Monday, February 24.

The course addresses questions many people are asking today: Do dreams have meaning? Is there such a thing as destiny? What does Judaism say about astrology and the ‚Äúevil eye‚Äù? How does Jewish tradition understand souls and the afterlife?

Drawing on¬†Talmud, Jewish philosophy, and Kabbalah, Jewpernatural offers a grounded, thoughtful approach to topics that often generate curiosity, skepticism, and uncertainty.

The four sessions include:

Dreams & Direction

Stars & Signs

Jinx & The Evil Eye

Para & Normal¬†(souls, angels, spirits, and the afterlife)

‚ÄúPeople are curious about these topics, but they also want serious, authentic answers,‚Äù said Rabbi Menachem Landa of Chabad Jewish Center of Novato. ‚ÄúThis course helps participants separate myth from meaning and gain practical Jewish perspective for real life.‚Äù

The course is open to all, regardless of background or prior Jewish learning.

Event Details What:¬†Jewpernatural (4-weekcourse) When:¬†Begins Monday, February 24 Where:¬†Chabad Jewish Center of Novato Format:¬†In person and Zoom Registration:¬†Jewishnovato.com/Jewpernatural Contact:¬†info@Jewishnovato.com

title: Mark Hummel‚Äôs Blues Harmonica Blowout
description:
**Mark Hummel‚Äôs 35th Annual Blues Harmonica Blowout with Mark Hummel, Magic Dick, Steve Freund, Anson Funderburgh, Rodrigo Mantovani, RJ Mischo, Curtis Salgado, and drummer Wes Starr.**

Mark Hummel‚Äôs Blues Harmonica Blowout‚Ñ¢ started on a Sunday night in 1991 at Ashkenaz in Berkeley with four harmonica players: Rick Estrin,¬†Mark,¬†Dave Earl and Doug Jay. Each player performed a twenty-to-thirty minute set, and everyone jammed together with Hummel‚Äôs Blues Survivors as backup. Over the next five years, it grew to become a multi venue event around California and included bigger names like William Clarke, Norton Buffalo, and Paul DeLay.¬†By the year 2000 the Blowout was headlining Yoshi‚Äôs in Oakland as a four-night show with Rod Piazza, Kim Wilson, Rick Estrin, James Harman and Billy Branch. These shows were recorded for Mountain Top Records.¬†¬†

Since then, the Blues Harmonica Blowout has become a who‚Äôs who of older and younger players, black, white, male and female, national, and international. From icons like Snooky Pryor, Carey Bell, James Cotton, Charlie Musselwhite, John Mayall, John Hammond, Little Sonny, Lazy Lester, Billy Boy Arnold, Sam Myers, Corky Siegel, Magic Dick, Huey Lewis, Lee Oscar, Jerry Portnoy, Howard Levy and Paul Oscher to younger players like Sugar Ray Norcia, Jason Ricci, Son Of Dave, Aki Kumar, Curtis Salgado, Kenny Neal, RJ Mischo, Sugar Blue, Annie Raines, Carlos Del Junco, just to name a few.¬†

The selection of guitarists has also been a stunner including Duke Robillard, Rusty Zinn, Bob Welsh, Little Charlie Baty, Anson Funderburgh, Jr. Watson, Billy Flynn, Steve Freund, Mike Keller, and many more.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: The Art Of Acrylics
description: Suzanne will demonstrate each week as students follow along with weekly painting projects, exploring techniques such as layering thick and thin paint, using gels and palette knife, and applying color theories. Students can work on their own projects as well. Whether you're a beginner or looking to refine your skills, this class covers everything you need to know. You'll get informed instruction on how to begin a piece, from choosing the right materials to selecting the perfect color palette. We'll dive into composition techniques to help you craft a balanced, captivating piece, and walk you through the finishing touches that bring your work to life. Suzanne's artwork ranges from portraits, figurative genre, landscapes and caricatures. She has exhibited in juried shows including The Society of Illustrators in New York and for 10 years at the Southern California Laguna Beach Art Festival. She has taught classes and workshops for many years and led lecture-demos at art associations from California to Washington State. For enrollment and supply list, please text or call Suzanne Carson at 707 888 2083

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9‚ÄìMarch 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of¬†bonsai and the season‚Äôs first flowers.¬†Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year‚Äôs all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai‚Äîtrees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot¬†bonsai¬†take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal‚Äîreminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from¬†hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through¬†Hanami Strolls‚Äîguided walks through the Garden‚Äôs Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE¬† 2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:¬† February 23 ‚Äì March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery‚Äôs free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.¬† Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women‚Äôs History Month. Shore‚Äôs watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.¬† These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.¬† A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in ‚ÄúGood Point.‚Äù¬† The artist takes us into nature with ‚ÄúRedwood Rendezvous‚Äù where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.¬†¬† ¬†‚ÄúJust Back from Vegas‚Äù captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.¬† ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic ‚Äì women deserve nothing less,‚Äù noted Shore.¬†

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

¬†The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer‚Äôs Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.¬† Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with ‚Äúla belle vie.‚Äù The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in ‚ÄúCaf√© le Bistro‚Äù, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.¬† One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer‚Äôs unique view of the Eiffel Tower in ‚ÄúParis is for Lovers.‚Äù ‚ÄúEvery day was an adventure in Paris ‚Äì I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there‚Äù, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am ‚Äì 6 pm.¬†¬†¬† **www.upstairsart gallery.net**

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: Next-Level Drawing
description:
Schedule

Wednesday, March 11 ‚Äì April 22, 2026 11:00 AM ‚Äì 1:00 PM

Location

Room 208

Experience Level

Intermediate

Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$225 ‚Äì Registration CostAdvance your drawing skills with deep study of composition, value, and technique. Strengthen your creative process through focused practice.

About the Class

In this class, we will explore composition, value, and other aspects of drawing but on a deeper level. Beginning drawing classes have a lot of ground to cover so the concepts are skimmed over in order to give you exposure to as many as possible. Next-level drawing takes the time to do a deeper dive into some of the principles of drawing. When drawing we use limited tools which allow us to isolate both our strengths and weaknesses. Using this opportunity to really investigate our own process will serve to strengthen all aspects of our creative work. Drawing can be a challenge but when you see how it enhances the creative process, you will know it is worth it. This class is suitable for students who have a basic understanding of drawing and want to work on their skills. Please bring the following materials to class: 20‚Ä≥ x 26‚Ä≥ drawing board with clips, 18 ‚Äúx 24‚Äù Strathmore drawing pad \(other brands are fine as long as the paper is drawing quality\), soft willow charcoal, compressed charcoal \(Char-kole brand black\), white plastic eraser, notebook, Staedtler drawing pencils 2B and 6B, Pigma micron pens black \(one fine-tip and one medium-tip\).Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

title: Free Estate Planning Webinar
description:
Creating your estate plan, whether it‚Äôs a living trust or a will, can be a daunting task.¬† Estate planning addresses issues that are difficult to think about, such as death, incapacity, finances, and family dynamics.¬† It can be easy to procrastinate, even though these issues may weigh heavily on your mind.

We invite you to attend one of our upcoming free webinars so you can take the first step toward having peace of mind by creating \(or updating\) your estate plan.¬† This is an educational webinar, where we highlight some of the concerns that many families face and how an estate plan can help.¬† The attorneys also break down how wills and trusts differ, and some of the common estate planning pitfalls and how to avoid them.

Our goal is to provide you with the education you need to protect yourself and your family, and leave a legacy of peace. If you would like to set up a meeting to discuss your estate planning needs further, we offer all participants who complete the webinar a free, no obligation personal consultation with one of the attorneys.

At this webinar, we will discuss several common issues and concerns, including:

The advantages and disadvantages of wills, living trusts, and probate

Protecting your children‚Äôs inheritance from their future ex-spouses, lawsuits, and other claims

Most living trusts fail; if you already have a trust, find out what you can do to ensure that it will protect you and your loved ones

How to preserve your nest egg for your family if you find yourself needing Long Term Care

title: Creative Flow: Explore, Create, Renew
description:
Schedule

Wednesdays, February 4 ‚Äì February 25, 2026 5:30 PM ‚Äì 8:30 PM

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Categories: Drawing & Painting, Wellness

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$200 ‚Äì Registration Cost $25 ‚Äì Materials Fee $225 ‚Äì Total Registration CostExplore body, mind, and imagination through movement, art, and writing in this beginner-friendly, four-week class. No experience needed-just curiosity!

What you‚Äôll do

Based on the Tamalpa Life/Art Process, founded by Anna Halprin, this four-week class invites participants to explore the connection between body, mind, and imagination through gentle movement, art-making, and writing. Each session blends simple, creative activities designed to transform life experiences into art and open new possibilities for personal renewal. In a supportive and beginner-friendly environment, students will deepen self-awareness, express emotions, and discover fresh perspectives. No prior dance or art experience is required‚Äîjust curiosity and an open heart. Course Format and Weekly Outline: Session 1 ‚Äì The Call & Crossing the Threshold: Mapping the Self Theme: Where am I now? Practices: Guided movement warm-up; sensory awareness; movement exploration of stepping toward/away from a ‚Äúthreshold‚Äù; body mapping with paint/collage; reflective writing. Outcome: Participants identify their current state and set creative intentions for the series. Session 2 ‚Äì Trials & Allies: Shadows and Strengths Theme: Meeting obstacles and discovering resources. Practices: Movement exploration of ‚Äúallies and shadows‚Äù; expressive drawing/painting; optional mask or small clay object; reflective writing; small-group witnessing. Outcome: Students recognize inner strengths and gain flexible tools for navigating emotions and challenges. Session 3 ‚Äì Ordeal & Transformation: Release and the Boon Theme: Releasing old patterns and discovering new insights. Practices: Grounding movement; movement ritual exploring ‚Äúwhat I am ready to release‚Äù; creation of the ‚ÄúBoon‚Äù object or image; reflective writing. Outcome: Participants experience personal renewal and create a symbolic object representing newly gained insight. Session 4 ‚Äì Return with the Elixir: Integration & Wholeness Theme: Carrying creative insight back into everyday life. Practices: Movement exploration of ‚Äúpathways of return‚Äù; creation of a triptych \(Before / Crossing / Return\); gallery walk and group witnessing; closing ritual with shared intentions. Outcome: Students integrate learning and leave with practical creative practices for ongoing self- discovery and stress relief. Learning Outcomes: 1. Develop greater self-awareness by exploring personal experiences through movement, art-making, and reflective writing. 2. Use creative tools for well-being, including techniques for emotional expression, personal renewal, and stress reduction. 3. Strengthen confidence and connection through supportive group activities and experiments with expressive movement and visual art.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: Yoga Vinyasa Krama
description:
Nataraja School of Traditional Yoga
**Yoga Vinyasa Krama - Thursdays 9-10:30am**
**Soft Medicine Sanctuary - Loft**

Experience physical health & fitness, pranic flow, vital energy & stillness - through intelligent architecture with the metaphysics of deep conscious breathing & slow motion, yogic breathwork, mantra/sound/vibration, mudra, subtle & contemplative practices.

Yoga Vinyasa Krama is a comprehensive hatha-raja yogic system for purification, developing concentration, neuromuscular fitness and conditioning, mastering the breath, awakening subtle energy and stilling the mind. Based on deep breathing & the subtle movement of prana directed into the cartilage tissue, sinuous musculature, internal organs, nerve pathways and nadis. It has over 700 intelligently sequenced slow, conscious breath powered with precision movement variations with pause (vinyasas), exploring many aesthetic variations of each posture to correctly establish the main asanas while the mind merges with the breath.
Includes drishti, pratikriyas, bandha, vaseth, mudra, mantra, surya & ding namaskar with breath & mantra, cleansing kriyas, Himalayan pranayama including including ujjayi variations, heating & cooling breaths, solar, lunar & soli-lunar nadi shuddhi practices, pranava & samantraka pranayama, pratyahara, subtle & contemplative practices in 12 kramas (sequences).

The whole process gradually transforms the body and mind, releasing old patterns of physical and mental tension and dysfunctional patterns of movement, providing tonic, energetic and psychophysiological effects. This system is presented from the teachings Srivatsa Ramaswami learned through his over 33 years of one on one study with Sri Krishnamacharya and teachings from a similar Himalayan method.

This ongoing class will explore the entire system of 12 Kramas with each class focusing on a particular krama (sequence) & pranayama & contemplative practices.

Please practice on an empty stomach. Morning beverage ok but please take it 30min or more before class.

$25 Drop In, Discounted Class Passes & Memberships
Register -[https://momence.com/Soft-Medicine-Sanctuary/Yoga-Vinyasa-Krama-/122789095?skipPreview=true](https://momence.com/Soft-Medicine-Sanctuary/Yoga-Vinyasa-Krama-/122789095?skipPreview=true)

title: Oil Portrait in Four Steps with Maggie Parr
location: Rileystreet Art Supply,103 Maxwell Ct, Santa Rosa, CA 95401, USA
description:
Instructor: Maggie Parr
Thursday mornings from February 19th-March12th
10:00 am-1:00 pm
$225 + materials
Limited to 10 students (first 4 students to register get a free ¬Ω hour private consult with
Maggie)

Oil painting doesn‚Äôt have to be intimidating! In just four weeks, students will paint a portrait in the indirect style, starting with a grey value study, building up with layers, and finishing with powerful details. The final result always surprises people: just by following basic rules, anyone can create a beautiful oil portrait that glows. Even abstract
painters can benefit from learning these techniques. Knowing how oil painting works give us more confidence to develop our own authentic creative voice. As Maggie says, ‚ÄúYou gotta learn the rules to break the rules.‚Äù


Maggie Parr started her career destroying Lichtenstein prints that didn‚Äôt make the edition at Gemini G.E.L., where she learned that the behemoth art market would not be conducive to her spiritual and personal paintings. She started working as a show designer at Walt Disney Imagineering, where for the next three decades, she designed theme park attractions around the world. She also expanded into book illustration, murals, portraits,
comics, and eventually, writing books and scripts for television. Along the way, she studied with master teachers like Steve Huston, Jeremy Lipking, and
Joseph Q. Daily. She spent years experimenting to find her own creative voice‚Äîa fusion of expressionism and realism. She got an MFA and taught at the college level, then developed her own teaching methods for private and group study.

Today, Maggie maintains a thriving business creating custom art and designs for corporations, individuals, and non-profits. She teaches other artists to utilize classical rendering techniques so they can confidently break the rules in the service of their own
work. And she coaches creatives in search of deeper authenticity, healing, and self- actualization.

Please follow the link to register for this class https://www.parrcreate.com/page/676799 www.parrcreate.com/page/691159 https://www.parrcreate.com/page/691159 https://www.parrcreate.com/page/691159

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9‚ÄìMarch 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of¬†bonsai and the season‚Äôs first flowers.¬†Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year‚Äôs all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai‚Äîtrees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot¬†bonsai¬†take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal‚Äîreminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from¬†hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through¬†Hanami Strolls‚Äîguided walks through the Garden‚Äôs Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description: New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

title: Art Exhibit: Celebrating Women
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE¬† 2/13/26

**MARCH EXHIBIT: CELEBRATING WOMEN**

EXHIBIT DATES:¬† February 23 ‚Äì March 29, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 2026, 4-6 pm: Join in to meet the artists and celebrate the show. Take part in the Gallery‚Äôs free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.¬† Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artist, **Tosya Shore,** presents **Celebrating Women,** paintings that commemorate women in honor of Women‚Äôs History Month. Shore‚Äôs watercolor works capture women in their element, showing the multiple facets of their lives.¬† These dynamic paintings break away with strong shapes and interlacing patterns that draw the viewer in exciting ways.¬† A la Degas, we catch a ballet dancer lacing her shoes in ‚ÄúGood Point.‚Äù¬† The artist takes us into nature with ‚ÄúRedwood Rendezvous‚Äù where dominant trunk shapes frame a couple enjoying a glorious forest scene.¬†¬† ¬†‚ÄúJust Back from Vegas‚Äù captures a fleeting view of elegance as the woman in question catches her breath.¬† ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs such special feeling in these everyday moments, I love to turn the mundane into magic ‚Äì women deserve nothing less,‚Äù noted Shore.¬†

Meet the artist: Shore will be hosting the Gallery on March 5 and 19 from 11am to 6 pm.

¬†The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Donna Schaffer‚Äôs Ooh La La, Plein Air,** a collection unveiling oil paintings made on her recent trip to France.¬† Roaming the streets of Paris, toting paints and palette, Schaffer captured iconic scenes buzzing with ‚Äúla belle vie.‚Äù The viewer catches a true cultural vibe in ‚ÄúCaf√© le Bistro‚Äù, the site of a favored hangout for espresso and conversation.¬† One is awed by the structure rising from the ground-level trees in Schaffer‚Äôs unique view of the Eiffel Tower in ‚ÄúParis is for Lovers.‚Äù ‚ÄúEvery day was an adventure in Paris ‚Äì I hope through these plein air vignettes, to share the excitement of being there‚Äù, stated Schaffer.

Meet the artist: Schaffer will be hosting the Gallery on March 21 and 22 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am ‚Äì 6 pm.¬†¬†¬† **www.upstairsart gallery.net** 

For further information: Contact: Beverly Bird, Press Contact, at bvdrio@sonic.net or 707-799-1490.

Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. $95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description: Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: Be Not Afraid Writing Workshop with Marilyn MacEntyre
description:
February 26-28, 2026

St Columba‚Äôs Writing and Spirituality Series presents Be Not Afraid: Finding Words that Equip us for the Moment. This spring in-person writing retreat led by Marilyn MacEntyre follows her successful online workshops and in-person retreats in 2023-25.

We are delighted to invite you to her 2026 spring offering, this retreat will run February 26-28 2026, 4:00 pm Thursday through 3:00 pm Saturday.

Escalating political conflict, a polarized economy, ongoing warfare, and climate anxieties give us plenty of occasion to come face to face with our fears. We may have to dig deeper for hope these days, but we know where to find it. In our hours together we'll be reflecting on how "Be not afraid" comes to us not simply as an admonition but as an invitation, and how even in the midst of troubles, both public and personal, we can help each other find our way back to the heart of God in whom we can find both our own peace and the courage to be peacemakers.

Writing exercises will focus on experiences of fear, courage, consolation, and resilience in the historical moment we share and in our own sometimes shadowy paths.

Marilyn McEntyre, writer and longtime professor of literature, coaches writers and teaches in programs at New College Berkeley, Western Theological Seminary and the Oblate School of Theology. Her books include Caring for Words in a Culture of Lies, When Poets Pray, and Speaking Peace in a Climate of Conflict. A new book about writing, Start With a Word, is coming out in February 2026 and can be pre-ordered at eerdmans.com. See more, and contact her, at marilynmcentyre.com.

Cost: $295-$695 depending on choices about lodging/commuting

Partial scholarships available¬†

Register at https://www.stcolumbasinverness.org/be-not-afraid

$25 ‚Äì One Bag or Doll Entry $40 ‚Äì Two Bags or Dolls entryTransform plastic dolls and create upcycled bags from trash into unique art. Join our hands-on Trashion workshop for the Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction.

About the Class

This hands-on workshop invites participants to rescue and reinvent plastic dolls \(Barbies, Kens, and dolls that are under 12 inches\) often destined for landfills, where they can take 20 to 500 years to decompose. As part of Trashion Season, join us for the beloved Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction \(April 3 ‚Äì 25\) where discarded materials are transformed into small-scale works of art for a good cause. Together, we‚Äôll reclaim these forgotten figures and reimagine them as expressive, one-of-a-kind artworks for submission to the gallery exhibit and auction. New this year: Bags! In addition to dolls, we‚Äôre expanding the exhibit to include bags‚Äîthink totes, clutches, cross bagsm fanny packs, coin purses, and backpacks. Just like the Trashion runway, the only rule is that your piece must be made from unconventional materials and/or upcycled/used textiles. Participants will have access to access to sewing machines, hot glue guns, irons, hair dryers and other creative tools as well of a wide selection of trash and upcycled materials to bring their vision to life. BYOT \(Bring your own trash\) is also welcome and encouraged! The workshop registration is your application fee to the gallery exhibit! Come play, experiment, and collaborate while contributing to a dynamic gallery exhibit that raises funds for Sonoma Community Center programming through the auction. It‚Äôs a joy to see your art find a new home‚Äîand to be part of a creative community turning trash into treasure.

Thank you to Recology Sonoma-Marin for donating Barbies & Dolls for our gallery exhibit every year.

Encaustic painting is an ancient technique that involves using molten beeswax and pigments to create stunning, textured masterpieces. This unique medium allows for endless possibilities, as it can be layered, carved, scraped, and fused to create mesmerizing effects and depth. From ethereal landscapes to abstract creations, encaustic painting offers a truly immersive and tactile experience.¬†

title: Oil Painting Atelier: Guided Growth & Project Realization
description:
Thursdays, January 8 ‚Äì February 26, 2026 5:00 PM ‚Äì 8:00 PM

Intermediate and Advanced

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$350 ‚Äì Registration Cost

A mentored studio for long-term oil painting projects with personalized guidance, weekly reviews, and support tailored to each artist‚Äôs level and goals.

What you‚Äôll do

This continuous Atelier studio offers sustained, personalized mentorship for students working on long-term oil painting projects. It is structured to serve artists at various stages of development, from those applying foundational knowledge to advanced students exploring profound expressive concepts.

Phase 1: Project Proposal & Private Consultation: All students submit a project proposal. You will meet individually and privately with the instructor to define the scope, set challenging yet achievable goals based on your current skill level, and create a comprehensive roadmap for the duration of the course. This ensures a productive and focused experience, regardless of whether you are a recent beginner or an advanced painter.

Phase 2: Weekly Problem-Solving Studio: You work independently on your project, benefiting from the structure of a studio environment. The instructor conducts weekly, dedicated review time, providing customized guidance. This support scales precisely to your needs, ensuring you receive the appropriate technical advice to overcome obstacles specific to your project and your level of experience.

Integration with The Chromatic Voice \(taught on Monday mornings\): This course is the essential practical partner, ensuring that both foundational knowledge and advanced conceptual exploration are successfully translated into realized, high-quality paintings. Prerequisite: Students must have completed at least one introductory course in oil painting or demonstrate equivalent foundational knowledge \(e.g., knowledge of basic setup, brush cleaning, and layering principles\).

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

title: THIRSTY THURSDAY New Member Social for Sonoma County Women's Wine Club
description:
Sonoma County Women's Wine Club (SCWWC)
This is our regular club meeting, held on the last Thursday of every month except for holidays and we are super excited! Come join us at 4th Street Cellars in downtown Santa Rosa. They have generously offered to host our monthly THIRSTY THURSDAY social for us.

If you are new to the area, or just looking to get out of the house and make new friends, this is the place for you. Welcoming to ALL new and (ahem, old) members.

Wine is purchased by the glass for a set fee of $13/$14 per glass with the variety of white, ros√©, and red wines offered through 4th Street Cellars which includes tip. Fees are collected at the venue by Co-organizer Daima Phipps via cash, Venmo, or Paypal. You are welcome to purchase wine separately if you choose. Starting March 2025, we ask that every attending member pay a $1 "slush" fund fee per event so that we can build up our funds for club-related expenses, which can be paid by Venmo or cash.

There is no food offered, but you are welcome to bring an appetizer or snack to share with the group, and many ladies do. We will have time to socialize while tasting in the room upstairs to the left or the outside patio if the weather is nice.

The space has a 25 person attendee limit, but the list is open to 40 to eliminate a waitlist, and guests are welcome! Please RSVP below only if you are able to make it, we have an attendance policy: if you No-Show to three events, you may not attend events for the next three months. Please put this event in your calendar so you don't miss out or get dinged. A No-Show is when you are on the 'Going' list, but do not show up.

See you there, ready to kickoff!

title: When Whales Speak - Presentation by Firuze Gokce
description:
Join the Laguna de Santa Rosa Foundation in welcoming artist and marine conservation advocate Firuze Gokce for an inspiring talk that blends art, science, and storytelling. In this presentation, Firuze shares her creative process of transforming whale songs, spectrograms, and real marine research into vibrant visual art. Through the true stories of individual whales and the scientific discoveries behind her pieces, she explores how storytelling can spark emotional connection and drive conservation action. This talk invites audiences to listen more deeply to the ocean, understand the lives of the whales who inhabit it, and discover the power of art as a voice for the natural world.

Firuze Gokce reached a significant milestone with the debut of her first solo art exhibition on May 23rd, showcasing her "Whale Sounds on a Canvas" collection. This exhibition featured her prints and immersive videos that blended visual art with the auditory experience of whale songs, offering a multi-sensory exploration of marine life. Firuze‚Äôs innovative approach incorporates actual whale sound recordings into her artwork. Additionally, her piece "Brave Little Hunter" was requested by Bay Cetology on Vancouver Island, highlighting her ability to convey the emotional depth of the natural world. Firuze was also accepted into the prestigious Sonoma County Art Trails Program in October 2024, further solidifying her place in the art community. Her artwork ‚ÄúDiving into the Depths of the Ocean‚Äù received an ‚ÄúHonorary Mention Award‚Äù from the Marine Society of Artists.

Guests are welcome to arrive early and enjoy Firuze Gokce‚Äôs art exhibit, Whale Sounds on a Canvas II, currently on view at the Laguna Environmental Center from January 10 ‚Äì April 24, 2026.

title: Sip, Savor, Serve fundraiser Feb. 26 in Healdsburg
description:
An event to raise funds for refurbishing the parish-hall kitchen at St. Paul's Episcopal Church takes place on Thursday, Feb. 26, in Healdsburg. "Sip, Savor, Serve" begins at 6 p.m. at the Paul Mahder Gallery, 222 Healdsburg Ave., and will feature wine, hors d'oeuvres and a silent auction with many tantalizing prizes, among them trips to lovely resorts, tickets to a San Francisco Giants baseball game with an overnight stay in that city, restaurant gift certificates, merchandise from high-end women's clothing stores, hair salon gift certificates, wine experiences and much more.

St. Paul's is a leader in serving Healdsburg residents who need food, personal care items, a place to take a hot shower, or assistance with transportation and clothing. The church's Shower Ministry is open three days per week and in 2025 provided 1,164 showers. Every Tuesday the church serves a hot soup-and-bread luncheon. Food is available the other two days the Shower Ministry is open each week. And the parish hall at 209 Matheson St. is the site of Healdsburg's weekly Sunday dinner. Produced by a cooperative of seven of Healdsburg's churches, the Sunday meal traditionally served about 40 people weekly but in recent months has grown to serving 80 or more.

The cost of producing the fundraiser has been covered by sponsors. All money raised from ticket sales and the silent auction will be used for upgrading the parish hall facilities. Tickets are $125 each and are available through Eventbrite; go to www.eventbrite.com and search "Sip Savor Serve" for Feb. 26.
